Text: Lord, You have been our dwelling place through all generations.
Context: The psalmist acknowledges God as the eternal home and protector of His people.

Text: Before the mountains were born, before You gave birth to the earth and the world, from everlasting to everlasting, You are God.
Context: Recognition of God's eternal existence and power in creation preceding all things.

Text: You return man to dust and say, "Return, O children of men."
Context: A reflection on the mortality of humans in contrast to God's immortality.

Text: For in Your sight a thousand years are but a day that passes, or a watch in the night.
Context: Expresses the timelessness of God in comparison to human perception of time.

Text: You sweep them away in the sleep of death—they are like the new grass of the morning:
Context: An illustration of the transience of human life compared to the eternal nature of God.

Text: In the morning it springs up new, but by evening it is dry and withered.
Context: Continues the metaphor of grass to describe the brief and fragile nature of human life.

Text: For we are consumed by Your anger and terrified by Your indignation.
Context: Speaks to the reality of God's judgment and wrath upon sin.

Text: You have set our iniquities before You, our secret sins in the light of Your presence.
Context: Confession of sin and acknowledgment of God's complete awareness of human failings.

Text: For all our days decline in Your fury; we finish our years with a sigh.
Context: Bemoaning the human experience of life weighed down by the consequences of sin.

Text: The length of our days is seventy years—or eighty if we are strong—yet their span is but trouble and sorrow, for they quickly pass, and we fly away.
Context: Realism about the hardships of life and the swift passage of time.

Text: Who understands the power of Your anger? Your wrath matches the fear that is due You.
Context: A rhetorical question emphasizing the fear and respect that God's power and anger ought to inspire.

Text: So teach us to number our days, that we may gain a heart of wisdom.
Context: Petition for God to impart wisdom to live life in light of its brevity and eternal perspective.

Text: Relent, O LORD! How long will it be? Have compassion on Your servants.
Context: An appeal for God's mercy and an end to suffering.

Text: Satisfy us in the morning with Your loving devotion, that we may sing for joy and be glad all our days.
Context: Requesting that God's steadfast love be experienced, leading to joy and gladness.

Text: Make us glad for as many days as You have afflicted us, for as many years as we have seen evil.
Context: A prayer to balance past afflictions with future joy.

Text: May Your work be shown to Your servants and Your splendor to their children.
Context: Asking for God to reveal His deeds and glory to His people and their descendants.

Text: May the favor of the Lord our God rest upon us; establish the work of our hands for us—yes, establish the work of our hands.
Context: A prayer for God's blessing and the prosperity of their endeavors.
